diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: Kawasaki disease is a rare condition that mainly affects children under the age of 5. It's characterized by inflammation of blood vessels throughout the body and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms. Key features include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, redness in the eyes, lips, and throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: Scarlet fever is a bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It's marked by a bright red rash on the body, often with a texture like sandpaper. Along with the rash, people have high fever, sore throat, and red, swollen tonsils.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms include flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters, eventually leading to the top layer of the skin dying and shedding.

diagnoses.name: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
diagnoses.description: DRESS syndrome is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, hematologic abnormalities (eosinophilia), and involvement of internal organs. It's a hypersensitivity reaction to certain medications.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or 'the kissing disease,' this infection is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and is spread through saliva. Symptoms include fatigue, sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes in the neck and armpits, swollen tonsils, headache, and skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: Measles is a highly contagious infectious disease caused by the measles virus. Symptoms typically include fever, cough, runny nose, inflamed eyes, and a rash that spreads over the body.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus infection
diagnoses.description: Adenoviruses are a group of common viruses that cause a range of illnesses, with symptoms including cold-like symptoms, sore throat, bronchitis, pneumonia, diarrhea, and pink eye (conjunctivitis).

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections, often associated with the use of superabsorbent tampons. Symptoms can include sudden high fever, low blood pressure, vomiting or diarrhea, rash, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Hand, foot, and mouth disease
diagnoses.description: A mild, contagious viral infection common in young children, characterized by sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet. It's typically caused by a coxsackievirus.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. Often a reaction to a medication or an infection.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can develop in people who have strep throat. Characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening skin condition that causes the skin to blister and peel off. Often related to a reaction from a medication.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A drug reaction that can cause a variety of symptoms including fever, rash, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's typically seen in children under 5 years old.

diagnoses.name: Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidney's filtering units. It can lead to blood in the urine (hematuria), proteinuria, and reduced kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects the blood and blood vessels. It results in the destruction of blood platelets, a low red blood cell count (anemia), and kidney failure.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels that can cause rash, abdominal pain, and kidney issues.

diagnoses.name: Acute Pyelonephritis
diagnoses.description: A sudden and severe kidney infection. This condition causes the kidneys to swell and can cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with widespread systemic manifestations including acute nephritis, pericarditis, fever, neurological symptoms (including delirium), and cutaneous manifestations such as atrophic scarring.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Infective endocarditis can lead to fever, embolic renal infarction (which could manifest as nephritis), pericarditis (especially if the infection spreads or there's an immune response), and immune complex deposition leading to skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.reasoning: Rheumatic fever, a complication of untreated or inadequately treated strep throat, can cause fever, acute nephritis, carditis (which can involve the pericardium), and various skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Viral Myocarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain viral infections can lead to myocarditis that may present with systemic symptoms including fever, delirium (due to systemic illness or complications), and potentially affect the kidneys indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus
diagnoses.reasoning: Some drugs can induce a lupus-like syndrome with symptoms including fever, nephritis, pericarditis, and possibly skin manifestations similar to those of systemic lupus erythematosus.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin (leading to atrophic scarring), kidneys (nephritis), heart (pericarditis), and can also cause fever and neurological manifestations similar to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Extrapulmonary tuberculosis can involve the kidneys (renal tuberculosis), pericardium (tuberculous pericarditis), skin (scarring from lupus vulgaris), and potentially cause fever and systemic symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This disease combines features of multiple connective tissue diseases and can include symptoms like nephritis, pericarditis, fever, neurological symptoms, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Septicemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Bloodstream infections can have widespread effects including fever, altered mental status (delirium), indirect effects on the kidneys (nephritis), and can lead to pericarditis as a complication.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Behçet's disease can affect multiple organ systems, leading to symptoms such as fever, potentially affecting kidneys (glomerulonephritis), causing inflammation of the heart (pericarditis), and skin manifestations, including scarring.

diagnoses: Infectious Mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)
Primary immunodeficiency diseases (e.g., Common Variable Immunodeficiency)
Phrynoderma (vitamin A deficiency related to follicular hyperkeratosis)

Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with ITP)

Cancer (such as lymphoma or lung cancer)

Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune psychosis)
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Hashimoto's Thyroiditis (as part of Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome)
Mental disorders due to a general medical condition

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including psychosis (neuropsychiatric SLE), proteinuria (kidney involvement), arthropathy and synovitis (joint involvement), and pericardial effusion (cardiac involvement).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing joint inflammation, severe cases can lead to systemic symptoms including proteinuria (due to amyloidosis), and pericardial effusion. Rheumatoid Arthritis does not typically cause psychosis, suggesting the need for an alternative or additional diagnosis to account for this symptom.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by skin thickening, this condition can also lead to internal organ involvement. Renal crisis can cause proteinuria; it can also present with arthritis and pericardial effusion, but psychosis is not a common manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This condition features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include psychosis, proteinuria, joint issues, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the exocrine glands but can have systemic manifestations. Although rare, it can present with kidney involvement (proteinuria) and arthropathy. Psychosis is very rare; if present, another overlapping condition might be considered.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause inflammation of the joints (arthropathy) and tendons (potentially leading to synovitis) but is not typically associated with proteinuria, pericardial effusion, or psychosis unless there is an overlap with another condition.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the spine but can also have peripheral joint involvement (synovitis, arthropathy). Renal involvement is rare, hence proteinuria, pericardial effusion, and psychosis would suggest a different or additional diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It can cause arthritis and, rarely, kidney disease (proteinuria), but it does not typically cause pericardial effusion or psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the heart valves, it can lead to pericardial effusion and can manifest with Osler nodes (causing joint pain) and kidney damage (proteinuria). Psychosis can occasionally occur due to systemic illness effects or embolic strokes.

diagnoses.name: Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Typically follows a streptococcal infection, leading to acute kidney injury presenting as proteinuria. Joint pain can occur, but it does not commonly cause synovitis, arthropathy, pericardial effusion, or psychosis.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not directly related to the primary disease)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Parvovirus B19)
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin C, Vitamin A)

diagnoses.description: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
Viral Laryngitis
Generalized Anxiety Disorder
Vasovagal Syncope
Marfan Syndrome
Bacterial Laryngitis
Orthostatic Hypotension
Cushing's Syndrome
Autonomic Dysreflexia

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that results in recurrent attacks of angioedema, or episodes of swelling. This condition might also cause abdominal cramping, leading to bloating.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: A form of arthritis that primarily affects the spine, causing inflammation, chronic back pain, and stiffness. It can also cause systemic symptoms like fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a variety of symptoms, including episodic weakness, hyperthermia, and arthritis with back pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that can cause episodic weakness, chronic pain, and in some cases, swelling or bloating as part of gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like bloating, and it may also lead to episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition where mast cells excessively release chemical mediators, leading to symptoms such as angioedema, episodic weakness, and potentially hyperthermia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive, leading to symptoms including episodic weakness, and can also contribute to bloating and chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria
diagnoses.description: A group of liver disorders that result from a buildup of natural chemicals that produce porphyrin in the body, leading to symptoms such as episodic weakness and possibly hyperthermia.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Patients often report chronic back pain and episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, leading to bloating and occasionally systemic symptoms like fever (hyperthermia).

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhoids
diagnoses.description: Swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that cause discomfort and bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in high blood sugar (glucose) levels, affecting glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Lymphadenitis
diagnoses.description: The inflammation of lymph nodes, which can be a sign of an infection or, rarely, a cancer in the body.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic, progressive condition in which the heart muscle is unable to pump enough blood through to meet the body's needs for blood and oxygen. It can cause migratory edema.

diagnoses.name: Venous Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition where the flow of blood through the veins is inadequate, causing blood to pool in the legs. It can contribute to swelling and might be related to hemorrhoids.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The gradual loss of kidney function, which can contribute to a variety of complications, including fluid retention (edema), anemia, and disordered electrolyte levels.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that affect the thyroid gland, which can influence energy levels, mood, metabolism, and potentially contribute to attention deficit and glycemic lability issues.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious illness caused by the Epstein-Barr virus that can cause lymphadenitis, fatigue, and more.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, which can cause fatigue, impacting attention and potential migratory edema.

diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with secondary infection
Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Irritable Bowel Syndrome, Crohn's Disease)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause increased levels of basophils and is associated with polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to produce too many red blood cells. It can indirectly lead to basophilia and is directly associated with polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma cancer originating from white blood cells (lymphocytes) that often results in lymphadenitis and can feature itching (pruritus) as a symptom.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer that originates in the lymphatic system and can cause lymphadenitis and generalized itching.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic Infections
diagnoses.description: Infections caused by parasites such as filariasis or schistosomiasis can cause lymphadenitis, pruritus, and in some cases, polycythemia due to an increased red blood cell mass as a response to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as psoriasis or eczema, including dyshidrotic eczema, that can lead to chronic inflammation and may be associated indirectly with conditions like polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that leads to an increase in blood cell production, including basophils, and can cause symptoms like pruritus and polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Severe allergic reactions can result in increased basophil levels and cause symptoms like dyshidrotic eczema and migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis that can cause chronic inflammation, leading to lymphadenitis and potentially affecting blood cell counts indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.description: An acquired form of polycythemia occurring in response to factors like prolonged hypoxia, which can also influence the elevation of basophils and other symptoms like pruritus.

diagnoses: Insomnia due to Mental Health Disorder

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS can cause irregular menstrual cycles, which might explain dysmenorrhea and could potentially lead to miscarriage. Insulin resistance is also a feature, contributing to glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Progesterone Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition is rare but can cause skin manifestations including edema, triggered cyclically in relation to menstrual cycle, potentially explaining migratory edema and dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause a wide range of symptoms including arthritis (which might be misinterpreted as migratory edema), miscarriage due to antiphospholipid syndrome, and plethoric facial rash.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders (Hypothyroidism/Hyperthyroidism)
diagnoses.reasoning: Thyroid dysfunction can explain menstrual irregularities (dysmenorrhea), miscarriages, and glycemic lability. Hypothyroidism can also lead to edematous states.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition leads to overproduction of cortisol which can cause plethora, menstrual irregularities potentially leading to dysmenorrhea, and it can impact glucose metabolism, hence, glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to glycemic lability. While it's more indirectly associated with the other symptoms, its complications can be wide-ranging.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: This myeloproliferative disorder increases the blood cell count, leading to plethora. It doesn’t directly cause the other mentioned symptoms but can contribute to vascular complications.

diagnoses.name: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
diagnoses.reasoning: CHF can cause fluid retention leading to edema. While not a direct cause of the other symptoms, its systemic impacts could potentially exacerbate underlying conditions affecting menstrual cycles and miscarriage rates.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.reasoning: APS is known for causing recurrent miscarriages and is associated with systemic autoimmune conditions such as SLE, which could indirectly contribute to the other symptoms through systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Luteal Phase Defect
diagnoses.reasoning: A defect in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle can cause miscarriages and severe menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea). It's more specifically related to reproductive issues than the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding due to unusually low levels of platelets.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin K Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Insufficient vitamin K leads to reduced blood clotting, causing easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Cancer of blood-forming tissues, hindering the body's ability to fight infection and leading to anemia, bleeding, and lymph node swelling.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus compromises the immune system, leading to severe infections and diseases such as lymphadenopathy and vaginal infections.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, leading to a wide array of symptoms including dermatographism and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy and possibly affecting blood cell production and immune system function.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Anemia caused by a shortage of iron in the body, leading to fatigue, weakness, and in severe cases, increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.description: A disease causing inflammation and bleeding in the small blood vessels, leading to rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Gonorrhea
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted bacterial infection that can cause vaginitis, may lead to skin problems or generalized infection affecting multiple organ systems.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
diagnoses.description: An infection of the female reproductive organs often caused by sexually transmitted bacteria. It can cause vaginal discharge, pain, fever, and can lead to long-term pelvic pain.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition, often brought on by stressful situations and extreme emotions, where the heart's left ventricle weakens and balloons. Surprisingly, it mimics a heart attack but usually doesn't involve blocked coronary arteries.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilia
diagnoses.description: A higher than normal level of eosinophils (a type of white blood cell) in the blood, which can indicate a variety of conditions including allergies, infections, and some autoimmune diseases.

diagnoses.name: Seizure disorders
diagnoses.description: A broad term that encompasses any condition in which episodes of uncontrolled electrical activity in the brain cause convulsions or other symptoms. Epilepsy is the most well-known of these disorders.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder characterized by the overproduction of eosinophils, leading to inflammation and damage to various organs, including the heart, which may result in conditions like myocarditis, potentially aligning with symptoms of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A common chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Cough is a common symptom. Eosinophilia can occur in allergic asthma.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
diagnoses.description: An adverse drug-induced reaction that involves skin rash, eosinophilia, fever, and involvement of internal organs. It’s a severe condition that can overlap with several of the symptoms mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by asthma, high levels of eosinophils, and vasculitis.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic infection
diagnoses.description: Infections caused by parasites can lead to eosinophilia. Certain parasites, especially those that invade the tissues such as in toxocariasis or echinococcosis, can lead to systemic symptoms, including cough and potentially influencing seizure disorders.

diagnoses.name: Oral lichen planus
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory condition affecting mucous membranes inside the mouth, causing pain, redness, swelling, and sore patches. Although it doesn't directly relate to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or eosinophilia, it can contribute to oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body, causing a cough and potentially leading to systemic symptoms like eosinophilia through immune response.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by excessive worry and anxiety, occurring more days than not for at least six months, about a number of activities or events.

diagnoses.name: Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder
diagnoses.description: A severe form of premenstrual syndrome that causes significant distress or functional impairment, potentially explaining symptoms of dysmenorrhea and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by hormonal imbalance, often presenting with dysmenorrhea, that could indirectly contribute to anxiety through its impact on a patient's quality of life.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest, which could present with symptoms such as anxiety and sleep disturbance.

diagnoses.name: Panic Disorder
diagnoses.description: A type of anxiety disorder characterized by unexpected and repeated episodes of intense fear accompanied by physical symptoms that may include chest pain or heart palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep, potentially leading to symptoms such as chest pain and contributing to anxiety due to disturbed sleep.

diagnoses.name: Mitral Valve Prolapse
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the valve between the heart's left upper chamber and the left lower chamber doesn't close properly, which can cause chest pain and may be associated with anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick, making it harder for the heart to pump blood; it can lead to chest pain and potentially contribute to anxiety symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of the uterus grows outside the uterus. It can cause severe dysmenorrhea and potentially lead to anxiety due to chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels which can be described as angiomata. It is included due to the symptom of angiomata, though it may have less direct connection to the other symptoms listed but warrants consideration based on comprehensive patient assessment.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Alopecia Areata, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms including constipation and pain that could affect multiple body systems.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Glycemic lability points to issues with blood sugar regulation, which could cause vision problems and contribute indirectly to other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to dysmenorrhea, and its associated insulin resistance can explain glycemic lability. PCOS may also contribute indirectly to other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities (such as dysmenorrhea), constipation, and difficulties with vision focusing.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Explains widespread pain including chest pain, can be associated with IBS (thus explaining constipation), might cause menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea), and cognitive issues affecting focus.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myocardial Ischemia
diagnoses.reason: Chest pain is a key symptom, and while the other symptoms are not directly related, systemic effects and stress from chronic pain can exacerbate or mimic these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Can cause or exacerbate chest pain, lead to gastrointestinal issues like constipation, affect glycemic control, contribute to menstrual irregularities, and impair concentration.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.reason: While not directly causing all these symptoms, depression can exacerbate or be associated with a variety of physical symptoms including those listed due to poor self-care and stress.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.reason: Directly causes dysmenorrhea and might be related to gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation; it can also indirectly affect overall health, potentially exacerbating other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reason: MS can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including difficulty focusing vision. Other symptoms might be less directly linked but can appear as part of the overall impact of MS on the body.

diagnoses: Autoimmune thyroiditis (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis in transient phase)
Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs) with cyst formation

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with exacerbation
Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient hyperthyroidism
Secondary Hypertension due to Endocrine Disorders
Infections (e.g., HIV, syphilis) causing cognitive and systemic symptoms
Hormonal imbalances (e.g., thyroid disorders) affecting memory and body temperature
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus) with neurological and systemic manifestations
Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., B12, folate) causing cognitive and hematological abnormalities
Malignancies (e.g., lymphoma) with neurological and systemic symptoms
Mental Health Disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety) causing or exacerbating memory problems
Constitutional Delay of Growth and Puberty
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells due to insufficient iron, potentially causing fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra, often causing pain and urgency with urination.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from not enough vitamin B12 which can lead to anemia and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A common, chronic, and long-lasting disorder in which a person has uncontrollable, recurring thoughts (obsessions) and behaviors (compulsions) that they feel the urge to repeat over and over.

diagnoses.name: Acute Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the middle ear, leading to pain and possibly fever. It is common in children.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). It can cause a variety of symptoms and may affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It may cause vision problems and is also associated with fatigue which can indirectly contribute to cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can lead to difficulties in eye movement and focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause a variety of symptoms, including anemia, due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that occur when the thyroid gland either underproduces or overproduces the thyroid hormones. Can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including potential effects on mood and cognitive function.

diagnoses: Vitamin and Mineral Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Folate deficiency)
Hepatitis (viral, autoimmune, alcoholic, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and dry mouth, along with potential digestive issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose), can lead to dyslipidemia and is a risk factor for urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder that affects the lower esophageal sphincter, leading to dyspepsia and potentially contributing to ulcer formation.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition where open sores develop on the inside lining of your stomach and the upper portion of your small intestine, causing ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including the joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs, and can cause a wide variety of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic liver disease that can lead to digestive issues, often associated with autoimmune disorders like Sjögren's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that affects the lining of your joints, but can also cause dry eyes and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It can lead to dyslipidemia and increase the risk of ulcers due to imbalances in the body's chemistry.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, can lead to dyslipidemia and has been associated with an increased risk of Sjögren's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that causes bladder pressure, bladder pain and sometimes pelvic pain, which could be related to the symptom of dyspepsia and urinary tract-like symptoms without infection.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may lead to symptoms like vulvodynia, memory problems, and systemic symptoms such as bloating.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Sjögren's syndrome is an immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause vaginal dryness (which could be associated with vulvodynia), as well as systemic symptoms such as bloating and memory issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes mellitus is a group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). While it primarily leads to elevated blood sugar levels, it can cause complications such as hypoglycemia (especially in those being treated for diabetes), and might contribute to memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: IBS is a common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both. IBS doesn't directly cause vulvodynia, memory problems, dry eyes, or hypoglycemia, but it can exist comorbidly with conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: Depression is a common but serious mood disorder. It can cause severe symptoms that affect how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. Symptoms can include changes in sleep, appetite, energy level, concentration, and can indirectly lead to or worsen conditions like hypoglycemia due to changes in appetite or eating habits.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: CFS is a complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. It may include memory problems, sore throat, headaches, and unexplained pain, potentially overlapping with symptoms like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Thyroid disorders, including hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism, can impact virtually every metabolic process in the body. Symptoms can include fatigue, weight changes, memory problems, and menstrual irregularities that could indirectly contribute to conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Lupus is a systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and renal dysfunction, potentially overlapping with memory problems and systemic symptoms like bloating.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: PCOS is a condition that affects a woman's hormone levels, leading to irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth, acne, and obesity. It is associated with insulin resistance, which could lead to hypoglycemia, and its hormonal imbalances might indirectly contribute to symptoms like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders weaken the immune system, making it easier to get infections and harder to fight them off. Some of these infections or the inflammation caused by a weakened immune system can affect the body systemically, potentially leading to symptoms like fatigue, bloating, and memory problems.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Urticarial reactions (including allergic reactions to drugs, foods, insect bites)
Foreign body in the respiratory system

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms include swelling (angioedema), difficulty breathing (dyspnea), and low oxygen levels in the blood (hypoxia).

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes episodes of severe swelling, especially of the face and airways, and abdominal cramping due to diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the conjunctiva (the membrane that covers the white part of the eyes and the inner side of the eyelids) usually caused by allergies. While not directly accounting for angioedema or hypoxia, it may be seen with other allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Carboxyhemoglobinemia (Carbon Monoxide Poisoning)
diagnoses.description: Exposure to carbon monoxide gas causes headache, dizziness, nausea, cough, dyspnea, and hypoxia due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood.

diagnoses.name: Septic Shock
diagnoses.description: A serious condition that occurs when an overwhelming infection leads to life-threatening low blood pressure. Symptoms may include hypoxia, diarrhea, and in severe cases, skin manifestations such as angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections. Symptoms include fever, rash, skin peeling, and a rapid onset of severe symptoms including hypoxia and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: ACE Inhibitor Induced Angioedema
diagnoses.description: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, which are used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure, can cause angioedema, particularly swelling of the face and airway which may lead to difficulty in breathing.

diagnoses.name: Foreign Body Aspiration
diagnoses.description: Inhaling or choking on an object can obstruct airflow and cause dyspnea, hypoxia, and possibly trigger an inflammatory response leading to symptoms that might mimic some allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
diagnoses.description: A serious lung condition causing low oxygen levels in the blood (hypoxia). It can cause severe shortness of breath and usually occurs in people who are very ill with another disease or condition.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly and affect the whole body, including skin (pruritis, angioedema), cardiovascular system (hypotension, syncope), and potentially cause incontinence due to loss of control over bodily functions.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the adrenal glands leading to insufficient production of certain hormones, causing symptoms such as hypotension, syncope, and skin changes which may appear as pruritis or hyperpigmentation rather than angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic Shock
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from damage to the nervous system, which can lead to hypotension, syncope (fainting), and potentially incontinence due to loss of control over the bladder.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure leading to fainting, often in response to a trigger such as stress or pain and can be accompanied by hypotension and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A complication of diabetes that affects the autonomic nervous system, leading to symptoms including hypotension, syncope, and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodes of severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the airways, limbs, and intestines. It can lead to abdominal pain and in some cases, hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where mast cells accumulate in the skin and other parts of the body, causing symptoms such as pruritis, syncope, hypotension, and in rare cases, urinary incontinence due to bladder involvement.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Progressive loss of kidney function that can lead to a buildup of fluids and waste in the body, causing symptoms such as incontinence, hypotension, and in certain cases, pruritis due to uremic frost.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare, progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects the body's autonomic functions, leading to severe orthostatic hypotension, incontinence, and in some cases, stridor due to vocal cord paralysis which could be confused with angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Dysreflexia
diagnoses.description: A condition primarily seen in individuals with spinal cord injury that can cause a sudden and severe increase in blood pressure, but may also present with hypotension, incontinence, or pruritis due to overreaction of the autonomic nervous system.

diagnoses: Toxic ingestion (e.g., certain drugs, toxic plants)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms include hives, angioedema, difficulty breathing, and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body, which can cause hives, angioedema, and in severe cases, hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Food allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune response to eating certain foods. Common symptoms include abdominal pain, hives, pruritis, and could lead to anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Insect sting allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the venom from a sting. Symptoms can include hives, edema, hypotension, and can escalate to anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Drug allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction after taking a certain medication. Symptoms may include rash, hives, itching, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disease characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin, bone marrow, and internal organs. Symptoms can include abdominal discomfort, pruritis, and anaphylactoid reactions.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that causes episodes of severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the abdomen, limbs, face, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: Anaphylaxis with no identifiable cause. Symptoms are similar to anaphylaxis but occur without a known allergen trigger.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria
diagnoses.description: Also known as hives, urticaria presents as red, itchy welts on the skin and may be accompanied by angioedema. Chronic cases can have recurrent symptoms without obvious triggers.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammation of the skin resulting from direct contact with allergens or irritants. Symptoms can include pruritus, red skin, and hives.

diagnoses: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) - less common for the given combination but can feature elements like urticaria and angioedema

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms include sneezing, hypotension, hives, and abdominal cramps. Conjunctival injection can also be present as part of the allergic response.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Also known as hay fever, it is an allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. It can occasionally lead to systemic reactions like hypotension in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include hives, abdominal cramps, and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Drug Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a medication. Symptoms can include hives, hypotension, and sometimes conjunctival injections.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting mast cells or mast cell activity in the body, which can cause symptoms such as hives, hypotension, and abdominal cramps in response to various triggers.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes recurrent episodes of severe swelling. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps and potentially life-threatening hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including rashes (hives-like), hypotension, and abdominal cramps, among many others.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to insect stings. In some cases, severe reactions can cause hives, hypotension, and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Latex Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the proteins in natural rubber latex. Symptoms can range from mild (hives, sneezing) to severe (hypotension).

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a range of symptoms depending on the type of vasculitis, including hypotension and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with acute flare
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) with neurological manifestations

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. These tumors can develop anywhere in your nervous system, including in your brain, spinal cord, and nerves. It is usually diagnosed in childhood or early adulthood.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a non-cancerous tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain. Because branches of this nerve directly influence balance and hearing, pressure from an acoustic neuroma can cause hearing loss, ringing in your ear and unsteadiness.

diagnoses.name: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
diagnoses.description: A group of hereditary disorders that damage the nerves in your arms and legs (peripheral nerves). It may cause muscle weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances such as flashes of light or blind spots, which can be accompanied by other disturbances including tingling on one side of the face or in an arm or leg and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. It can lead to brain damage and impair hearing.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. If left untreated, the infection can spread to the joints, the heart, and the nervous system, leading to a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A nervous system disease that weakens muscles and impacts physical function. Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it involves the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles.

diagnoses: Migraine with Brainstem Aura (previously known as Basilar-type Migraine)
Viral infection affecting the inner ear or brain
Hepatitis B and C related liver disease
Primary Angiitis of the Central Nervous System
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (as a specific diagnosis or reaction)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by autoantibodies that attack healthy tissues, potentially leading to the symptoms you've mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A general term for a group of uncommon diseases that feature inflammation of the blood vessels. Each type of vasculitis has its own characteristic pattern of symptoms, which might include a rash, kidney involvement and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by cryoglobulins in the blood, which are proteins that can precipitate at lowered temperatures. It can lead to skin rashes, joint pain, and kidney problems, along with the risk of anemia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatitis Herpetiformis
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition caused by a reaction to gluten ingestion that can lead to a blistering skin rash and is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease). It usually doesn't cause panniculitis but may lead to other complications.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening blood disease that causes red blood cells to break apart. Symptoms often include hemolytic anemia, fatigue, proteinuria, and possibly thrombosis, but it rarely presents with rash or panniculitis.

diagnoses.name: Sickle Cell Disease
diagnoses.description: An inherited form of anemia — a condition in which there aren't enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen throughout your body — this disease might present with hemolytic anemia and proteinuria. Rash is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder characterized by blood clots that form in small blood vessels throughout the body, which can lead to hemolytic anemia, proteinuria, potential rashes, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Schönlein-Henoch Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement, including proteinuria. It is more commonly seen in children than adults.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by an immune response against the body's own red blood cells, leading to their destruction (hemolytic anemia). Skin manifestations are less common, but autoimmune diseases can have a wide range of presentations.

diagnoses.name: Membranous Nephropathy
diagnoses.description: A kidney disorder that leads to changes and thickening in the kidney glomeruli's membranes. The condition can cause significant proteinuria, and while not directly linked to rash or anemia, it can coexist with conditions that have these symptoms.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin rashes, joint pain, kidney involvement (proteinuria), serositis (such as pericardial effusion), and mucosal ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including symptoms like hand swelling, Raynaud's phenomenon, muscle weakness, and signs such as pericardial effusion and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rashes. It can lead to postinflammatory dyspigmentation and nonscarring alopecia in some patients.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that typically causes dry eyes and dry mouth but can also lead to systemic manifestations such as kidney involvement (proteinuria) and nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can have systemic manifestations such as pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by systemic lupus erythematosus, mainly characterized by proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, including painful mouth sores (oral ulcers), skin problems, and potentially serious complications.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis is associated with other systemic symptoms, including arthritis.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Foliaceus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that causes blistering and erosions of the skin and mucous membranes, potentially leading to oral ulcers and nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause skin tightening and hardening. It can also affect internal organs, leading to symptoms like renal crisis (proteinuria) and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Schizophrenia (in the case of psychosis, if unrelated to the other symptoms)
Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B/C, which can cause proteinuria and leukopenia)
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Mixed connective tissue disease)
Drug reactions (e.g., due to certain medications causing cytopenias and mucocutaneous reactions)
Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Epilepsy (for seizures, with a separate reasoning for the others)
Lymphoma (can present with various systemic symptoms)
Infections (e.g., Tuberculosis, can cause multiple systemic symptoms)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. The disease can cause oral ulcers, hemolytic anemia, nonscarring alopecia, and lymphopenia as part of its clinical manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the immune system that can lead to an increase in the number of lymphocytes. It is associated with autoimmune manifestations such as hemolytic anemia and can present with oral ulcers and nonscarring alopecia. Lymphopenia is less common but can occur in specific settings.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body. Its symptoms include painful mouth sores, ulcers, hemolytic anemia in some cases, and can lead to various skin manifestations including alopecia. Lymphopenia is not a hallmark but can appear.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system produces antibodies that attack red blood cells, platelets, and sometimes white blood cells, causing hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. It may present with some of the symptoms mentioned but is less likely to directly cause all of them.

diagnoses.name: Aplastic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the body stops producing enough new blood cells. This can lead to fatigue, higher risk of infections due to lymphopenia, and sometimes oral ulcers. Nonscarring alopecia is less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A broader category that includes several types of lupus, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and cutaneous lupus erythematosus. These disorders can present with symptoms like oral ulcers, nonscarring alopecia, hemolytic anemia, and lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: While primarily known as a joint disease, it is a systemic autoimmune condition that can have extra-articular manifestations including hemolytic anemia and oral ulcers. Alopecia and lymphopenia are less common but can occur in the context of severe, systemic disease.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the glands that produce tears and saliva. It can be associated with other autoimmune conditions that could explain the hemolytic anemia, alopecia, and lymphopenia. Direct association with all these symptoms is more atypical.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Though not directly causing all mentioned symptoms, vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which could become hemolytic. Oral ulcers are a common symptom. Nonscarring alopecia and lymphopenia are less directly associated but can occur in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious Anemia
diagnoses.description: A type of vitamin B12 deficiency that occurs when the body cannot absorb enough of this nutrient from food. It manifests often with megaloblastic anemia that can appear as hemolytic in lab tests, along with oral ulcers. Alopecia and lymphopenia are not hallmark features but can present in severe deficiency.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
